titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Emery Roth Architectural Print Collection
1926-1947
PR 170
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jenny Gotwals

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from eroth.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-10T14:54-0500

did.physloc: Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections
did.abstract: 53 photomechanical prints showing both interior and exterior views of buildings in New York City designed by Emery Roth.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. See guidelines in Print Room for details.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from:
Rights and Reproductions The New-York Historical Society
170 Central Park West
New York, NY 10024
Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270
Fax: (212) 579-8794

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as Emery Roth Architectural Print Collection, PR 170, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Emery Roth (1871-1948) worked as an architect in New York City under his own name from 1898 to 1938, and after 1938 worked with his two sons as Emery Roth & Sons. Roth was a specialist in the field of apartment house design. He designed many notable and fashionable New York residential buildings including the San Remo apartment house, the Oliver Cromwell, Dorset, and Drake apartment hotels, the Ritz Tower, and the St. Moritz hotel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Emery Roth Architectural Print Collection spans the period from 1926-1947 and contains 53 prints showing both interior and exterior views of buildings designed by Emery Roth. Most are half-tone prints from photographs, several are reproduced from presentation drawings or renderings. Most are attributed to "Emery Roth, architect," but a few date from after 1938 and are by "Emery Roth & Sons, architects." The collection is arranged by type of building.

Buildings shown are mainly apartment houses and hotels, with a few religious facilities and office buildings. Few of the prints have dates, but those from photographs are all post construction. Many of the buildings shown here were completed in the second half of the 1920s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prints are arranged by type of building shown.
